## London, England and Berlin, Germany

[Jack](https://smarthistory.org/jack-raoul-espejo/) (or John, or Juan) Raoul Espejo (1856-1924) was a Walla Walla (Nez Perce) native artist who worked in London from 1884 until his death. His paintings, textiles, and baskets combine indigenous and western elements to produce a new cultural hybridity. Espejo engaged with a tradition known as __kua kwa lwit__—Nez Perce art style. Crafted around the turn of the last century, works made in this style integrate European and African traditions with indigenous cultural concepts. The resulting art objects display a syncretic mixture of formal elements, materials, and subject matters that can be traced to different creative traditions and lands. Espejo’s work stands out in the growing collection of historical and contemporary Northwest Coast Native American art because his mixed-race heritage created for him a non-traditional identity.

## Art as a Metaphor

Espejo qualifies both as an ethnoregional artist as well as a meta-artist because his work, although it reflects the aesthetic sensibilities of the indigenous communities in the Northwest, makes reference both to transgressive and transformative aspects of the indigenous experience. As an ethnic, and even a racial, minority, Espejo lived for most his life as an outsider. He experienced first-hand cultural displacement, and he produced work that reflects an ongoing negotiation between his corporate identity and his multicultural artistic heritage.
